channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2015 The New York Times Company

item.title: Rozsypne Journal: Mourning and Seeking Answers Where Malaysia Airlines Jet Fell to Earth
item.description: A year later, some residents of three villages in eastern Ukraine are taking matters into their own hands to commemorate the dead, and to help the investigation.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW E. KRAMER
item.media:credit: Uriel Sinai for The New York Times
item.media:description: Igor I. Tipunov at his home on Tuesday. The hole in his ceiling was made by a woman's body that crashed through after Malaysia Airlines Flight 17 was shot down last year.

item.title: E.C.B. Increases Emergency Loans for Greek Banks
item.description: The central bank said it would raise the line of credit for Greece’s banks by almost $990 million, in a sign that it plans to continue support as the county’s bailout negotiations continue.
item.dc:creator: JACK EWING
item.media:description: The European Central Bank effectively forced Greece's banks to close on June 29, when it capped the emergency cash it provides to them at €89 billion. That limit will now be €89.9 billion.

item.title: Cooling of China’s Stock Market Dents Major Driver of Economic Growth
item.description: The market rally had an outsize role in the economy, and the slump could put pressure on the government.
item.dc:creator: NEIL GOUGH
item.media:description: On Wednesday, China reported its economy in the second quarter increased by 7 percent, in line with government targets. Economists said the expansion had been helped by rising output from the financial industry.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: The Most-Viewed Fitting Room in China
item.description: China’s online censors are supposed to block pornography, yet a sex video shot in a Uniqlo clothing store in Beijing was almost impossible to avoid seeing this week.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: Thanks to a viral sex video, Sanlitun Village, a Beijing shopping mall, is now home to China’s most famous Uniqlo.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Google Maps Changes Name on Disputed South China Sea Shoal
item.description: Complaints were raised after the Internet giant dropped Scarborough Shoal, a longstanding name taken from a ship that smashed against it in 1784, and described the island as part of China’s Zhongsha chain.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: A Filipino businessman, Mel Velarde, pointing to a replica of a 1734 map he bought at auction in London that shows Scarborough Shoal as part of Philippine territory under Spanish rule. The Philippine government requested copies of historical maps for its arbitration case against China in The Hague.

item.title: Greece Might Be Better Off Outside Eurozone, German Finance Minister Says
item.description: The statement by Wolfgang Schäuble came just hours after the Greek Parliament reluctantly approved a package of economic policy changes demanded by Germany and other creditors.
item.dc:creator: MELISSA EDDY

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: A Greek Farce, Then Gloom
item.description: Leftist populism failed to win Greece a better deal. The real political winner is most likely to be the anti-European right.
item.dc:creator: IVAN KRASTEV

item.title: Op-Ed Columnist: The Door to Iran Opens
item.description: The nuclear deal increases the distance between Iran and a bomb and reduces its distance from the rest of the world.
item.dc:creator: ROGER COHEN

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: A Gap Lingers in Taiwan’s Wartime Memory
item.description: Some say a 1945 air raid on Taipei by American bombers has been ignored by the government, with no official events to mark its anniversary and no physical memorial for the dead.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: The Japanese Governor-General's Office, now the Presidential Office Building, suffered heavy damage in the May 31, 1945, bombing raid.

item.title: WikiLeaks Cables Show a Saudi Obsession With Iran
item.description: Saudi Arabia’s alarm over the nuclear deal comes after a trove of documents revealed its plans to limit the spread of Shiite Islam in Iran.
item.dc:creator: BEN HUBBARD and MAYY EL SHEIKH
item.media:credit: Tomas Munita for The New York Times
item.media:description: An image of King Salman of Saudi Arabia on a Riyadh street in May.

item.title: Japan’s Lower House Passes Bills to Give Military Freer Hand to Fight
item.description: The lawmakers endorsed Prime Minister Shinzo Abe’s legislation despite broad public opposition and the largest demonstrations in three years.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: JONATHAN SOBLE
item.media:description: Prime Minister Shinzo Abe in Parliament on Thursday. He has championed legislation that would give the Japanese military limited powers to fight overseas.

item.title: Clearing Hurdles to Iran Nuclear Deal With Standoffs, Shouts and Compromise
item.description: Over a period of years, American and Iranian negotiators came to understand what mattered most to each other. Then a brief alignment of personalities and events helped bring a deal to completion.
item.dc:creator: DAVID E. SANGER and MICHAEL R. GORDON
item.media:description: Secretary of State John Kerry, center, speaking with Secretary of Energy Ernest J. Moniz on Tuesday in Vienna.

item.title: Labor Scrutiny for FIFA as a World Cup Rises in the Qatar Desert
item.description: A report last year found that migrant workers, many hired to build World Cup sites in Qatar, work under conditions akin to indentured servitude.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: BARRY MEIER
item.media:description: Foreign construction workers leaving a construction site in Qatar, which is preparing to host the World Cup in 2022

item.title: Puerto Rico, Running Short of Cash, Misses a Debt Payment
item.description: The Public Finance Corporation, which helps the island’s government finance its budget deficits, failed to make a $93.7 million debt-servicing payment.
item.dc:creator: MARY WILLIAMS WALSH

item.title: Tunisia Hosts Security Meeting With Group of 7 to Discuss Terrorism Threat
item.description: The Tunisian government hosted a meeting to discuss what more can be done to secure the country after two attacks in recent months killed dozens of foreigners.
item.dc:creator: CARLOTTA GALL

item.title: ‘El Chapo’ May Have Used Bird to Test Escape Tunnel Air
item.description: Mexican authorities found a dead bird in the drug lord Joaquín Guzmán Loera’s cell, and think it may have been used the way miners once used canaries.
item.dc:creator: AZAM AHMED and PAULINA VILLEGAS
item.media:description: A journalist reported from the exit of the tunnel that the authorities said was used by the drug lord Joaquín Guzmán Loera to escape from a Mexican prison.

item.title: World Briefing: Cameroon: North Bans Burqas
item.description: Cameroon’s northern region has barred women from wearing burqas and face-covering veils after bombs carried by women in burqas killed at least 14 people.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Kazakhstan Expands Visa-Free Travel Program
item.description: The Central Asian nation will add 19 countries and principalities to the list of territories that do not require a visa for visits of up to 15 days.
item.dc:creator: DAVID M. HERSZENHORN

item.title: Nuclear Pact Raises Kin’s Hopes of Freedom for 3 Held in Iran
item.description: Relatives of three imprisoned Americans expressed optimism on Wednesday that the agreement had removed a significant political obstacle to efforts to secure their release.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE
item.media:description: Naghmeh Abedini, left, the wife of a prisoner, and Sarah Hekmati, the sister of another, at a congressional hearing in June.

item.title: Greece, Its Back to the Wall, Adopts Austerity Steps
item.description: Lawmakers approved a package of harsh austerity measures and economic policy changes that were required by its creditors as the terms of a $94 billion bailout package.
item.dc:creator: SUZANNE DALEY and JAMES KANTER
item.media:description: Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras in Parliament. He said the measures would avert a fiscal disaster.
